trees as well as thickets and blanketed with green grazing land much to the contentment of herbivorous mammals along with their predators.","\tA orange sky, clear of clouds, opened expansively until vanishing behind the peaks of the mountain range whose crests were shrouded with everlasting snow and whose foothills were carpeted with a dense forest, which made them almost impenetrable.","\tIn the heart of this valley subsisted Liinde'si, the southern outpost of the Jotari realm.","No rightly a town, no even a village, just two buildings and three or four tents around a well, which granted shelter for a garrison of eight warriors and their families, as well as some few furs traders.","Total population: 37.","However, considering that Liinde'si was the only post in the area, there was a tree, assisted him in getting a lower branch.","Seconds later the kid was lost in the abundant foliage and Katain went back to his post.","\tThe sun was already gone and the first shadows of the night visited the surroundings when Katain decided to check on the boy.","\tWhen getting close to the well Katain spotted five strangers around the pond, pulling water out of the well.","For the nature of the post it was not infrequent to see strangers at any given time.","Or at least that was what Katain thought at seen those five characters.","\t“Be welcome to our hospitality!” He saluted while nearing the strangers.","That would be his last greeting.","\tThe five strangers turned around and at sighting Katain they just vanished in thin air.","Katain had barely time to realize that those were not ordinary people but some eerie creatures, before his throat was slit from behind.","\tAsmaan's mother, who has been looking for the kid, witnessed the slaying and shrieked frightened.","In seconds the entire garrison was around the well, weapons in hands, just in time to see how a creature stabbed her in her back.","They charged outraged but didn't stand a chance against the heinous ["1058570","248498","English","Spanish",["Amen","Rain was falling today as strong as it was when it started falling, all of the sudden, three months ago.","If this wasn't a hill, he thought, we would be thirteen feet underwater by now.","But it was a hill, and the water goes down hills.","He didn't even remember how the sky looked like.","There where they.","The two of them.","Three, she corrected him.","Three, because the dos is also family.","The only thing that dog has served us is to make our food supplies end sooner, he corrected her.","Now you would dare to say we're four if there was a rat or a chicken on the hill.","But there was nothing left.","Except for them.","The three of them.","The Saint Isidore remained motionless looking through the window where it was placed since the rain started to ruin the harvest, almost three months ago.","It looks like he likes the rain, he thought, if he had it his way it would never stop raining.","He took the figure on his hand and felt the urge of throwing it away so it would break.","The truth was the destiny of Saint Isidore, the dog, even hers, didn't care anymore.","Thousands of little pieces...","The desperate shout.","Did you throw Saint Isidore out of the window!?","The insufferable crying.","He was the only one that could stop this rain sent to us by Satan!","The endless barks of the dog.","All-night-long.","The headache.","Only imagining the scene persuaded him to put back the saint to its place.","He felt miserable.","Again.","Rather, he realized again he was.","A cramp in his stomach made him forgot about the figure.","They hadn't eaten anything in weeks.","He didn't understand why they hadn't died yet.","At first he was waiting for the dog to die.","She would have never let him kill it, so he had no choice.","How much can a dog stand without eating?...","Apparently a lot, because after a week without food, the dog looked the same as always.","It must be eating something, and it eats all itself.","Now it was thin, but it didn't appear sick.","He desisted on waiting.","After that, he wanted to die.","It didn't matter.","The rain would never end anyway.","He thought about killing himself, but when he had the gun loaded he imagines himself devoured by the dog.","Never.","He threw the pistol downhill through the window.","Damn dog.","However, he recently realized the dog was not guilty.","The dog didn't put the statue on the window frame when it looked like it was going to clear up.","The dog didn't took his food and served it on its own plate.","The dog didn't start the rain.","The dog didn't yell at him without reason and the dog didn't expend the nights praying and crying.","In short, the dog didn't destroy the improvised raft because it was too dangerous for the dog.","It could drown.","But he didn't thought the dog cared about drowning.","No, the dog is not guilty.","When it dies I will eat it with honors.","It was easy to know who was, one way or another, the cause of that infinite rain.","He thought about killing her since he knew.","Then, when it clears out, I'll eat the dog.","He was thinking all of this while sit in a corner of the room that served as a living room, dining room and kitchen of the house.","In the other corner there was she.","She was caressing the dog.","Saint Isidore was between they both, without looking at them.","He was watching the rain.","He rose from the floor with a log in his hand.","The dog started barking.","He could not stand an interruption.","He took it from the back and threw it against the wall.","She stood still.","He went closer, but she was still there, like if she was dead.","Could she be dead?","He came closer to see if she was breathing and felt a bite in his leg.","He released the wood.","She got up like if she was waiting for the dog to defend her.","Like if everything was already planned.","She picked up the log, while he was struggling with the dog.","I told you the dog was untouchable, honey.","A thunder fell and, without knowing why, he remembered it was raining.","The dog tore apart a part of his leg and he finally took it off with a kick.","She rose the wood.","He wanted to step away to prepare a counter attack.","At least so she doesn't fuck me up badly.","But his injured leg couldn't stand his weight and he stumbled.","Saint Isidore wasn't waiting for that.","When he was just looking at the rain, he was attacked from the back.","By a clumsy slap, he flew away through the window.","Even with the rain the sound of Saint Isidore breaking in to pieces was perfectly audible.","Twenty-three.","Her eyes shone full of despair and rage.","He rose his arms crossed, to stop the hit, but an absurd idea made him lost concentration.","Twenty-three little pieces were way less than thousands little pieces.","The dog was running to him.","He closed his eyes.","The log fell from her hands at the same time the dog stopped barking.","He opened his eyes without knowing if he was still alive or not, but then he didn't care if he was.","He saw the other two looking stunned through the window, then he saw what they were looking at.","It was the sky.","--------------------","I know dialogues should have quotations marks, but I want the text to flow, so let it be a literacy whim xD","I hope you like the story!"],[[],[],[],["But it was a hill, Did you mean \"Would you dare to say....\""],[],[],[],["The Saint Isidore remained motionless looking through the window where it was placed [f-red]since[\/f-red] the rain started to ruin the harvest, almost three months ago.   Since would be correct in Spanish, but in English you would indicate the time passage with \"when the rain started...\" "],["It looks like he likes the rain, he thought, if he had it his way[f-blue],[\/f-blue] it would never stop raining."],["He took the figure[f-blue] in (note: whenever the preposition involves hands, it is usually \"in\" unless it's on the back of his hand)[\/f-blue] his hand and felt the urge of throwing it away so it would break.","He took the figure on his hand and felt the urge [f-red]of throwing[\/f-red] it away so it would break. to throw it..present tense "],["The truth was [f-blue]that (in most cases we drop the \"that\", but in this case, it makes it clearer that \"didn't care anymore\" is talking about \"the destiny\")[\/f-blue] the destiny of Saint Isidore, the dog, even hers, didn't care anymore.","The truth was the destiny of Saint Isidore, the dog, even hers, didn't care anymore. If you used \"that the destiny\" you'd say \"didn't matter anymore to him\".  Or you could say, The truth was he didn't care anymore about the destiny of ...\""],[],[],[],[],[],["The endless [f-red]barks[\/f-red] of the dog. \"barking of the dog\"  You need to use the verb form here because this is an action."],[],[],[],[],[],["Rather, he realized again he was [f-blue]miserable.[\/f-blue] (You need to repeat the adjective to make your meaning clear)"],[],[],[],[],[],["How much can a dog stand without eating?... It would be clearer to say \"How long can a dog last without eating?\""],[],["It must be eating something, and [f-red]it eats all itself.[\/f-red] I'm not sure if you mean to say \"it eats all by itself\" implying that the others don't see him eating.  "],[],["He [f-red]desisted[\/f-red] on waiting. While formally correct, desisted [f-blue]from[\/f-blue] is more formal and less colloquial speech than the rest of the story.  It would perhaps be better to say \"He stopped waiting\""],[],[],[],["He thought about killing himself, but when he had the gun loaded[f-blue],[\/f-blue] he imagines himself devoured by the dog.","He thought about killing himself, but when he had the gun loaded he [f-red]imagines[\/f-red] himself devoured by the dog. \"imagined\" himself.  Imagines would be present tense and he is thinking of himself in the future.  I think this is conditional tense. though I'm not sure of the tense but I know \"imagined\" would be correct."],[],[],[],[],[],["The dog didn't t[f-blue]ake (See: http:\/\/www.usingenglish.com\/forum\/ask-teacher\/22627-didnt-take-didnt-took.html)[\/f-blue] his food and served it on its own plate.","The dog didn't took his food and [f-red]served[\/f-red] it on its own plate. \"serve\" singular"],[],["The dog didn't yell at him without reason[f-blue], (there are two independent clauses here) [\/f-blue]and the dog didn't expend the nights praying and crying.","The dog didn't yell at him without reason and the dog didn't [f-red]expend[\/f-red] the nights praying and crying. \"spend the nights\"  Expend really has a slightly different meaning, usually referring to spending money."],[],[],["But he didn't th[f-blue]ink[\/f-blue] the dog cared about drowning."],[],["When it dies[f-blue],[\/f-blue] I will eat it with honors.","When it dies I will eat it with honor[f-red]s[\/f-red].   You only eat it with \"honor\" singular."],[],[],[],["He was thinking all of this while sit[f-blue]ting[\/f-blue] in a corner of the room that served as a living room, dining room[f-blue], (Oxford Comma)[\/f-blue] and kitchen of the house."],[],[],["Saint Isidore was between the[f-blue]m[\/f-blue] both, [f-red]without looking at them[\/f-red]. [f-blue](Better: looking away from them)[\/f-blue]"],[],[],[],[],[],[],["He went closer, but she was still there, [sline]like[\/sline] if she was dead.\"like\" is not necessary."],[],[],[],["She got up [sline]like[\/sline] if she was waiting for the dog to defend her. \"as if\""],["Like if everything was already planned. you could say \"like everything was planned\", or \"as if\" "],["She picked up the log while he was struggling with the dog."],[],["A [sline]thunder [\/sline] [f-blue]lightning bolt [\/f-blue]fell[f-blue], (two independent clauses here)[\/f-blue] and, without knowing why, he remembered it was raining.","[f-red]A thunder fel[\/f-red]l and, without knowing why, he remembered it was raining. ["1052932","248498","English","Spanish",["(Very) Short Story","He always thought he was the only one in the whole world, ","until he heard somebody announcing his death."],[[],[],[]]]
["1094009","248498","English","Spanish",["I've been busy in school...","...","So I bring you my homework (that I wrote in English, I hope my teacher doesn't mind it).","It's long, so it's ok if you just want to comment...","--------------------------------------------------------------------------","The Animal that Is Just Like a Distributed Operating System","In our beloved earth, there are some animals that act more or less like a distributed operating system.","There is one, though, that is even more similar to them than ants.","This animal can be found everywhere on earth.","It has a very prolific nature and has done lots of things through its evolution to adapt better to the diverse environments where it lives.","Its life begins when a female gives birth to it, usually in presence of other animals of the same species, in what appears to be some kind of show.","The first days of its live it can’t survive by itself, depending on her mother for everything, from eating to keeping it away of dangers.","In most cases the male progenitor also stays with the newborn and its mother, but that it’s not necessary for its survival, and there are thousands of known cases where it stays only with its mother.","In rare cases the newborn can survive without its mother.","After the newborn is able to walk, and sometimes even before, it’s taken by its parents to coexist with other youngsters, where they leave it sometimes to go look for food.","The newborn is supposed to be always guarded by another grown-up, sometimes younger than the parents, to prevent it from suffering injuries or attacks.","After some time, it coexists with different youngsters, always around its own age, as well as some other species of animals.","This process is always guarded by grown-ups, whom in this period don’t only look at them but teach them some survival skills.","This animal has the particularity of not (usually) mating after they are able to, but some time later.","That may because of outside factors, though, because it varies with regions and there are documents that prove that long ago the females mated just after their first menstruation.","Also, some recent studies suggest that mating ages started to get lower in the last years.","As almost every other animal, these animals are polygamists.","This has helped to their proliferation.","This species is also known for its violent temper, they kill other animals for food, but also for what it looks like mere fun.","Also, they usually kill each other, for food, territories or sexual partners.","It likes to stay in very big herds, and it’s rare when one of them lives completely alone (that usually ends with the animal killing himself).","Their organization is very layered and pyramidal, with few herd leaders and many members of the herd, some of them can even be sacrificed if the leader feels it’s the best for the herd.","When the animal grows old, its destiny depends on many factors through its live.","Its position in its herd changes the way it can spend its last years of life.","A herd leader can live peacefully once he has given the herd control to a younger member.","In the other hand, a low level member can only aspire to get attention from its closest relatives in the herd, and its dead will pass unnoticed to the herd.","As I have spoken about the life of this animal, now I would like to explain how does it relate to the five design principles of distributed systems.","First principle is Transparency.","Even when the whole herd is made of many members (from tens to thousands), we, as well as other herds, can easily group them into a herd with unique characteristics that not only makes it different from other herds, but a single force that can be moved to one direction if the leader wants to (using various methods).","The second principle is Flexibility.","As an animal that lives in herds, and those herds are stratified, you can easily compare them to a microkernel, where there’s one kernel that controls other modules that are in charge of the operations of the system.","The leader of the herd delegates some of its tasks to high-level members of the herd, and sometimes this repeats more times, until it gets to all the herd.","The third principle is Reliability.","Any member of the herd, even the leader, is not essential.","If it is sick, goes, changes of herd or dies, it gets replaced promptly, and even when if the member was important it generates some trouble, it’s absence doesn’t compromise the welfare of the herd.","Fourth principle is Performance.","Being a herd animal makes this point obvious.","It works way better in groups, grouping lets it achieve almost any goal that the herd leader wants to achieve.","It’s said that a herd focused in a goal can only be hampered by natural laws or by a more powerful herd.","The last principle is Scalability.","When a herd needs or wants (to achieve something faster, for example) more individuals, the new members can join it as it’s needed in a way almost unnoticeable, which makes this one of the best qualities of the animal.","As with distributed operating systems, the herd should be careful about new members that can affect negatively the whole system.","And this is how Homo Sapiens is, in my opinion, the animal that mos resembles a distributed operating system."],[[],[],["So I bring you my homework (that I wrote in English, I hope my teacher doesn't mind [sline]it[\/sline])."],[],[],["The Animal that Is Just Like a [sline]Distributed Operating[\/sline] System [f-blue]I'm not sure what you mean here. Perhaps \"like a distribution system\"?[\/f-blue]"],["[sline]In[\/sline] [f-blue]On [\/f-blue]our beloved earth, there are some animals that act more or less like a [sline]distributed operating[\/sline] [f-blue]distribution (?)[\/f-blue]system."],[],[],["It has a very prolific nature and has done lots of things through its evolution to adapt better to the diverse environments [sline]where[\/sline] [f-blue]in which [\/f-blue]it lives."],[],["The first days of its [sline]live[\/sline] [f-blue]life [\/f-blue]it can’t survive by itself, depending on [sline]her[\/sline] [f-blue]its' [\/f-blue]mother for everything, from eating to keeping it away [sline]of[\/sline] [f-blue]from [\/f-blue]danger[sline]s[\/sline]."],["In most cases the male progenitor also stays with the newborn and its mother, but that[sline] it’s[\/sline] [f-blue]is [\/f-blue]not necessary for its survival, and there are thousands of known cases where it stays only with its mother."],[],["After the newborn is able to walk, and sometimes even before, it’s taken by its parents to [sline]coexist[\/sline] [f-blue]be [\/f-blue]with other youngsters, [sline]where[\/sline] [f-blue]and [\/f-blue]they leave it sometimes to go look for food."],["The newborn is supposed to [sline]be[\/sline] always [f-blue]be [\/f-blue]guarded by another grown-up, sometimes [f-blue]one [\/f-blue]younger than the parents, to prevent it from [f-blue]s[sline]uffering injuries or attacks[\/sline][\/f-blue]. ["1063634","248498","English","Spanish",["Nightmare","She suddenly sat up on the bed, in the middle of the night.","Her body completely covered in cold sweat, breathing so fast.","She was so scared that it took her more than a minute to realize she was awake.","She put her hand on her chest, feeling how her heartbeat returned to normal.","Slowly.","She thought, to calm herself down, that such things couldn't exist.","\"Wake up...","Wake up!\", she had thought, and then she was in her bedroom.","Just her imagination.","She sighed, convinced.","She lied down again.","Just before she closed her eyes, she turned her head to the left.","And then she saw it.","\"Wake up!","Wake up!\", she said.","But it didn't work.","------","This story originally had no definite gender for the main character (because in Spanish you can avoid telling it, so I did).","I suppose this can't be achieved in English (except by using \"it\", but then it wouldn't look like a person @.@).","When translating I thought it would fit more for a girl (because even when the \"it\" thing would appear to be more terrifying if the character was male, it's more common for a girl to wake up scared of that, then the end is more surprising this way).","Anyway, short story this time so you don't lose so much time :3 thanks to everyone reading and correcting and commenting n__n!"],[[],["She suddenly sat up [sline]on the[\/sline] [f-blue]in [\/f-blue]bed, in the middle of the night."],["Her body [f-blue]was (the verb group (I don't know the technical name) is \"was covered\" here)[\/f-blue] completely covered in cold sweat, [f-blue]and she was[\/f-blue] breathing [f-blue]really[\/f-blue] fast.[f-blue] (\"Breathing so fast\" doesn't sound natural.)[\/f-blue]","[f-blue]I think if you made this just one sentence you could write it as \"She suddenly sat up in bed, in the middle of the night, completely covered in sweat, breathing fast. Then the descriptions are adjectives modifying \"she\" ... sat up in bed...\"[\/f-blue]Her body completely covered in cold sweat, breathing so fast."],[],["She put her hand on her chest, feeling [sline]how[\/sline][f-blue] (it's not needed here)[\/f-blue] her heartbeat returned to normal.","She put her hand on her chest, feeling [sline]how[\/sline] her heartbeat return[sline]ed[\/sline] to normal. [f-blue]This is all present tense.[\/f-blue]"],["Slowly. [f-blue]The story is still in present tense.[\/f-blue]"],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],["When translating I thought it would fit more for a girl (because even [sline]when[\/sline] [f-blue]though [\/f-blue]the \"it\" thing would appear to be more terrifying if the character was male, it's more common for a girl to wake up scared [sline]of that[\/sline],[sline] then[\/sline] [f-blue]and [\/f-blue]the end is more surprising this way). [f-blue]Oh my, this is a little machismo on your part. As a psychoanalyst I can tell you men too waken in terror![\/f-blue]"],["Anyway, short story this time so you don't lose so much time :3 thanks to everyone [f-blue]for[\/f-blue] reading[f-blue],[\/f-blue] correcting[f-blue], and[\/f-blue] commenting n__n!"]]]
["1074475","248498","English","Spanish",["Time Travel Paradoxes 1: The First Time Machine","\"Finally!\", said professor Wells a summer afternoon in the year 2063.","\"The first time machine!.\"","There was no doubt, he will now be the most famous scientist ever.","He smiled at the thought of his boss, Mr.","Bradbury, telling him hundreds of times he'll never achieve it.","But he had just done it, and now he could even quit his job.","Not only he could, but he will.","Next morning he would go with Mr.","Bradbury and he would tell him everything.","He'd tell him his plans of selling them massively and then he would look at his worried face and he would make fun of him.","\"Don't worry, I would give you one free when I start selling them!\", he would say laughing at Mr.","Bradbury.","She ran to the living room to tell her wife.","\"Honey!","I did it...!\", he started saying.","\"What did you do?\", she said.","\"I created a time machine!\", he said, euphorically.","\"Are you feeling well?\", asked her.","She didn't look surprised nor excited.","\"Everyone knows that the time machine was invented years ago by your boss, Mr.","Bradbury\".","-------------------------------------","This is a series of three stories, each unrelated to the other two.","Third one is very complex, but if you like this I'll keep posting them.","Thanks for your reading and for your corrections!"],[[],["\"Finally!\", said[f-blue] P[\/f-blue]rofessor [f-blue](Professor's part of the title, so it needs to be capitalized) [\/f-blue]Wells a summer afternoon in the year 2063.","\"Finally!\", said [sline]p[f-blue]P[\/f-blue][\/sline]rofessor Wells [sline]a[\/sline] [f-blue]one [\/f-blue]summer afternoon in the year 2063."],["\"The first time machine!\""],["There was no doubt[f-blue]; Remember, there is no punctuation between the verb introducing the list (in this case, \"are\"), and the first item on the list.)[\/f-blue] "],["They[f-blue]\/These[\/f-blue] [f-blue]are[\/f-blue] cook[f-blue]ed[\/f-blue] with spices ."],["I think I have to emphasize olive oil, bread and wine."],["Someone [f-blue]said[\/f-blue]: ","Someone [f-blue]said[\/f-blue]: "],["\"The kitchen is linked to our way of life, culture and history.\""],["The weather is important in the cultivation of this food and make[f-blue]s[\/f-blue] them taste different and better.","The weather is important in the cultivation of this food and make[f-blue]s[\/f-blue] them taste different and better.","The [f-red][sline]weather[\/sline][\/f-red] [f-blue]climate[\/f-blue] is important in the cultivation of this food and make them taste different and better.[f-blue] (Weather is fine, but I think \"climate\" is a little better because it means how the weather is in general, every year.)[\/f-blue] "],[],["[f-blue]The first thing my grandmother did when she woke up was put[\/f-blue] the saucepan in the fire. ["634181","121067","English","Spanish",["Birthday´s party","Yesterday I had the birthday ´s party of my smaller daughter.","I was thinking about how different it was with mine.","Now she give them invitation to her friends and they call me and they tell me if they came or not.","When I was a child I had my birthday with only a little friends and the party was something to eat and play.","Only I like now because it´s the time I can speak with other mothers and we exchange ideas.","I like these meetings with people who has friends too.","It´s to do something different.","Yesterday I began to read a book \" George´s Marvellous Medicine\"","It is funny and easy to read."],[["Birthday[sline][f-blue]´s[\/f-blue][\/sline] party [f-blue](It's always \"birthday party,\" because \"birthday\" is not possessive of \"party.\" You can say, \"Mary's Party,\" or \"Mary's Birthday Party,\" but not \"Birthday's Party.\" Does that mean sense? You can almost think of \"birthday party\" as one noun.\")[\/f-blue]"],["Yesterday I had [f-blue]a[\/f-blue] birthday[sline][f-blue] ´s[\/f-blue][\/sline] party [f-blue]for[\/f-blue] my [f-blue]younger (or youngest)[\/f-blue] daughter."],[],["Now she give[f-blue]s[\/f-blue] [sline][f-blue]them[\/f-blue][\/sline] invitation[f-blue]s[\/f-blue] to her friends and they call me and they tell me if they [f-blue]will[\/f-blue] came or not. [f-blue](You can't use \"them\" to refer to a group of people before you define who the group of people is. For example, you could say, \"She gives her friends invitations and they call me...\" \"They\" has already been defined, so using it here is OK, but having \"...gives them invitations...\" is confusing, because the reader doesn't know who \"them\" is.)[\/f-blue]"],["When I was a child I had my birthday with only a [f-blue]few[\/f-blue] friends and the party was [f-blue]a time[\/f-blue] to eat and play. [f-blue](Little=size, few=number. \"Something\" in this sentence is too ambiguous. Instead, use a phrase like \"a time to eat...\" or \"an occasion to eat...\")[\/f-blue]"],["I [f-blue]only[\/f-blue] like [f-blue]it now [\/f-blue]because it´s [sline][f-blue]the[\/f-blue][\/sline] time I can [f-blue]spend[\/f-blue] speak[f-blue]ing[\/f-blue] with other mothers and we exchange ideas. [f-blue](You can say, \"...it's time I can spend speaking with other mothers...\" or \"...it's the only time I get to spend speaking...\" depending on what you want to mean.)[\/f-blue]"],["I like these meetings with people who [f-blue]have[\/f-blue] friends too. [f-blue](\"Has\" goes with \"people,\" so it needs to be plural.)[\/f-blue]"],[],[],[]]]

["600608","121067","English","Spanish",["\"TAPAS\"","My friends know that I´m spanish and I want to share with you some word we have here:\"Tapas\".","If you look at the dictionary the meaning is something that cover the saucepan.","But the other meaning we have is more interesting.","When people think about Spain they think in different words...","maybe: flamenco dance, bullfighter, nap,tapas...","but today I want to tell you where it comes from the word \"tapas\".","A long time ago when people was going to the bar and asked a wine´s glass , the waiter served the glass cover with a piece of ham.","And why that?","For the flies.","The flies were one of the problems they had and I don´t think they had healthy conditions.","Nowadays, we say \"tapas\" ,small portions of distinct dishes or traditional products.","They are often taken in midday from noon until dinner time.","Tapas were served for free when you asked for an alcoholic drink.","Now is not so common to be free, we have to pay if we want they serve.","There are a variety of \"tapas\" .","You can make \"tapas\" with all types of food.","I loved to eat only with \"tapas\" ,it´s the way to eat a lot of different things."],[[],["My friends know that I´m spanish and I want to share with you [sline][f-red]some[\/f-red][\/sline] [f-red]a[\/f-red] word we have here: \"Tapas\"."],["If you look [f-red]in[\/f-red] the dictionary the meaning is something that cover the saucepan.[f-blue] (Looking \"at\" the dictionary would be as if you looked only at the cover of the dictionary. ["657136","86473","English","Spanish",["Who can find more English mistakes? (Please, not only grammar)","The Italian Languague.","\tSometimes people take up language courses in order to improve their skills at work when their boss ask for it; or children are pushed to study languages for their future.","However, it\/this doesn't always happen.","That is why, Italian is one of the most interesting languages in the world.","Nobody is forced to speak it.","Most of people usually learn it because of his beauty.","To understand why, it's important have a look to the history.","\tEuropean people spoke latin-derived dialects that gradually changed over the years, like French, Portuguese, Spanish and Italian.","What happended with France, Portuguese and Spain was a progressive evolution that was accepted by all their habitants.","But Italy was the exception.","One reason is that Italia wasn't a country for years.","It wasn't unified until 1861 meanwhile, It was completely disunited, and the territories that actually conform the country were governing by different countries.","\"All this internal division meant that Italy never properly coalesced, and Italian didn't either.","So it's not surprising that, for, centuries, Italians wrote and spoke in ["660219","86473","English","Spanish",["Italian Language's text.","Chapter 15.","The interesting thing about my Italian class is that nobody really needs to be there.","There are twelve of us studying together, of all ages, from all over the world, and everybody has come to Rome for the same reason—to study Italian just because they feel like it.","Not one of us can identify a single practical reason for being here.","Nobody’s boss has said to anyone, “It is vital that you learn to speak Italian in order for us to conduct our business overseas.” Everybody, even the uptight German engineer, shares what I thought was my own personal motive: we all want to speak Italian because we love the way it makes us feel.","A sad-faced Russian woman tells us she’s treating herself to Italian lessons because “I think I deserve something beautiful.” The German engineer says, “I want Italian because I love the dolce vita”—the sweet life.","(Only, in his stiff Germanic accent, it ends up sounding like he said he loved “the deutsche vita”—the German life—which I’m afraid he’s already had plenty of.) ","As I will find out over the next few months, there are actually some good reasons that Italian is the most seductively beautiful language in the world, and why I’m not the only person who thinks so.","To understand why, you have to first understand that Europe was once a pandemonium of numberless Latin-derived dialects that gradually, over the centuries, morphed into a few separate languages—French, Portuguese, Spanish, Italian.","What happened in France, Portugal and Spain was an organic evolution: the dialect of the most prominent city gradually became the accepted language of the whole region.","Therefore, what we today call French is really a version of medieval Parisian.","Portuguese is really Lisboan.","Spanish is essentially Madrileño.","These were capitalist victories; the strongest city ultimately determined the language of the whole country.","Italy was different.","One critical difference was that, for the longest time, Italy wasn’t even a country.","It didn’t get itself unified until quite late in life (1861) and until then was a peninsula of warring city-states dominated by proud local princes or other European powers.","Parts of Italy belonged to France, parts to Spain, parts to the Church, parts to whoever could grab the local fortress or palace.","The Italian people were alternatively humiliated and cavalier about all this domination.","Most didn’t much like being colonized by their fellow Europeans, but there was always that apathetic crowd that said, “Franza o Spagna, purchè se magna,” which means, in dialect, “France or Spain, as long as I can eat.” ","All this internal division meant that Italy never properly coalesced, and Italian didn’t either.","So it’s not surprising that, for centuries, Italians wrote and spoke in local dialects that were mutually unfathomable.","A scientist in Florence could barely communicate with a poet in Sicily or a merchant in Venice (except in Latin, of course, which was hardly considered the national language).","In the sixteenth century, some Italian intellectuals got together and decided that this was absurd.","This Italian peninsula needed an Italian language, at least in the written form, which everyone could agree upon.","So this gathering of intellectuals proceeded to do something unprecedented in the history of Europe; they handpicked the most beautiful of all the local dialects and crowned it Italian.","In order to find the most beautiful dialect ever spoken in Italy, they had to reach back in time two hundred years to fourteenth-century Florence.","What this congress decided would henceforth be considered proper Italian was the personal language of the great Florentine poet Dante Alighieri.","When Dante published his Divine Comedy back in 1321, detailing a visionary progression through Hell, Purgatory and Heaven, he’d shocked the literate world by not writing in Latin.","He felt that Latin was a corrupted, elitist language, and that the use of it in serious prose had “turned literature into a harlot” by making universal narrative into something that could only be bought with money, through the privilege of an aristocratic education.","Instead, Dante turned back to the streets, picking up the real Florentine language spoken by the residents of his city (who included such luminous contemporaries as Boccaccio and Petrarch) and using that language to tell his tale.","He wrote his masterpiece in what he called dolce stil nuovo, the “sweet new style” of the vernacular, and he shaped that vernacular even as he was writing it, affecting it as personally as Shakespeare would someday affect Elizabethan English.","For a group of nationalist intellectuals much later in history to have sat down and decided that Dante’s Italian would now be the official language of Italy would be very much as if a group of Oxford dons had sat down one day in the early nineteenth century and decided that—from this point forward—everybody in England was going to speak pure Shakespeare.","And it actually worked.","The Italian we speak today, therefore, is not Roman or Venetian (though these were the powerful military and merchant cities) nor even really entirely Florentine.","Essentially, it is Dantean.","No other European language has such an artistic pedigree.","And perhaps no language was ever more perfectly ordained to express human emotions than this fourteenth-century Florentine Italian, as embellished by one of Western civilization’s greatest poets.","Dante wrote his Divine Comedy in terza rima, triple rhyme, a chain of rhymes with each rhyme repeating three times every five lines, giving his pretty Florentine vernacular what scholars call “a cascading rhythm”—a rhythm which still lives in the tumbling, poetic cadences spoken by Italian cabdrivers and butchers and government administrators even today.","The last line of the Divine Comedy, in which Dante is faced with the vision of God Himself, is a sentiment that is still easily understandable by anyone familiar with so-called modern Italian.","Dante writes that God is not merely a blinding vision of glorious light, but that He is, most of all, l’amor che move il sole e l’altre stelle .",".",".","“The love that moves the sun and the other stars.” ","So it’s really no wonder that I want so desperately to learn this language."],[[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[],[]]]

["621544","168737","English","Spanish",["The Biorhythms","The biorhythms are natural cycles of energy, when we are born our energy is stable but the time pass the energy goes through periods of great energy and periods of low energia.","The periods refer to three aspects  the physical with periods of 23 days of 11 1\/2 of which half are high energy and the other 11 1 \/ 2 are low energy, emotional periods of 28 days of which 14 are high emotional energy and 14 low energy, and intellectual lasts 33 days of which 16 1 \/ 2 high energy and other low energy, the ideal is to have the three highest levels at the same time but often this is not so, I hope your biorhythms are high.","For more informatión.","http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Biorhythm"],[[],["The biorhythms are natural cycles of energy, when we are born our energy is stable but [f-blue]as time[\/f-blue] passes[f-blue],[\/f-blue] the energy goes through [f-blue]high and low [\/f-blue]periods [sline][f-red]of great energy and periods of low energia.[\/f-red][\/sline]"],["The periods refer to three aspects.
